abstract: Hebron Journal; shops along al-Sahla street in West Bank's Old City of Hebron slowly begin to open after being closed since 1994 by Israeli military responding to massacre at nearby tomb; local residents and officials doubt sincerity of Israel effort to revitalize now dilapidated stretch into thriving marketplace, as only 7 of 300 shops have been allowed to open and deliveries and visitors are thwarted by military checkpoints.
lead_paragraph: Once a thriving marketplace, al-Sahla Street had its businesses shuttered after a murderous rampage in 1994. Now a few are reopening. But how many, and how soon?

headline.main: Businesses’ Doors Creak Open in a West Bank ‘Ghost Town,’ Decades After Massacre
headline.print_headline: Years After Massacre, a West Bank ‘Ghost Town’ Stirs

snippet: Once a thriving marketplace, al-Sahla Street had its businesses shuttered after a murderous rampage in 1994. Now a few are reopening. But how many, and how soon?
